descriptions.description: More maintainer time increases the rate at which issues can be resolved.
A higher issue resolution rate increases the stock of closed issues.
A larger base of explicit knowledge enables more effective knowledge transfer through documentation.
Better documentation lowers the barrier to entry, increasing the potential joining rate.
Clear documentation helps contributors learn faster, increasing their skill-up rate.
A better project reputation attracts more potential contributors, increasing the joining rate.
A higher project reputation attracts more potential contributors, increasing the joining rate.
More feedback from users and developers can lead to the identification of new issues.
More open issues generate more feedback from users and contributors.
More open issues represent more work, stimulating contributors to create new pull requests.
A higher rate of new pull requests increases the stock of pull requests awaiting action.
New pull requests move into the 'under review' stock as they begin the review process.
A faster review rate decreases the stock of new pull requests awaiting initial attention.
Pull requests under review contain potential code improvements that enhance the source code's value.
Merging pull requests removes them from the 'under review' stock.
Rejecting pull requests removes them from the 'under review' stock.
Providing PR feedback is a core activity performed on pull requests under review.
A larger backlog of pull requests under review can increase the rate of rejections due to quality or relevance scrutiny.
More core developers reduce the average delay in providing pull request reviews.
Shorter review delays enable more timely and frequent feedback on pull requests.
New contributors gain experience over time, transitioning into the experienced contributors stock.
As contributors skill up, they transition out of the 'new contributors' stock.
Experienced contributors are promoted into the core developer role based on merit and involvement.
The promotion rate decreases the stock of experienced contributors as they move to core roles.
Constructive PR feedback helps experienced contributors refine their skills and understanding.
Receiving PR feedback is a primary learning mechanism for new contributors.
PR feedback helps core developers stay aligned on project standards and technical direction.
Experienced contributors provide valuable feedback due to their deeper project knowledge.
New contributors generate questions and discussions that lead to PR feedback.
PR feedback discussions are archived, contributing to the searchable knowledge base.
A larger stock of implicit knowledge is subject to greater loss through forgetting or context decay.
Higher developer turnover accelerates the loss of implicit, undocumented knowledge from the project.
Implicit knowledge held by contributors can be formalized and converted into explicit knowledge.
Converting implicit knowledge to explicit knowledge increases the stock of explicit knowledge.
Existing explicit knowledge provides a foundation for creating and converting more implicit understanding.
A rich base of implicit knowledge among core members enables more effective mentorship.
Effective mentorship directly accelerates the skill development of less experienced contributors.
Successful mentorship increases the rate at which contributors are promoted by building their competence.
More core developers increase the project's capacity for providing mentorship.
A comprehensive knowledge base directly adds to the project's stock of explicit knowledge.
Resolved issues and their solutions are documented, enriching the searchable knowledge base.
Community discussions generate insights and solutions that are added to the knowledge base.
Feedback from pull request reviews is documented and becomes part of the searchable knowledge base.
A higher issue creation rate increases the stock of open issues.
More source code provides a larger surface area for bugs and feature requests, increasing issue creation.
Resolving issues decreases the stock of open issues.
A higher adoption rate increases the size of the user base.
User churn decreases the size of the user base.
A larger user base contributes to project visibility and reputation through usage and advocacy.
Positive project activities and outcomes build up the project's reputation over time.
Negative events or poor project health cause a decline in project reputation.
High-quality software with good features enhances the project's reputation.
A large user base signals popularity and utility, bolstering the project's reputation.
A healthy, collaborative community positively reflects on and enhances the project's reputation.
Positive interactions and reliable contributions build trust, strengthening community health.
Toxic interactions and burnout erode collaborative norms, damaging community health.
